Graphical abstract MgO-CeO2 catalysts were investigated for selective synthesis of glycerol carbonate by glycerol transesterification with dimethyl carbonate as carbonating source. Co-precipitation technique was used to prepare Mg-Ce oxides by with different molar ratios. Samples characteristics were derived by N2 adsorption, XRD, FE-SEM, TGA-DTA and CO2 -TPD. The catalysts surface structural properties and basicity were directed by the composition of oxides and treatment temperature. The sample with 3:1 Mg/Ce ratio exhibited highest basicity. The same catalyst treated at a temperature of 650°C, exhibited highest glycerol carbonate yield of 86%. The reaction conditions were also optimized. Keywords Glycerol carbonate Glycerol Dimethyl carbonate Magnesium-cerium oxides Transesterification 1 Introduction Glycerol, a by-product obtained during the production of biodiesel. It was anticipated that about four billion gallons of glycerol could be produced by biodiesel industry. This will encourage to use glycerol as source as the cost of glycerol will substantially decrease in the market [1–3]. This led to find different glycerol applications for the preparation of variety of value added chemical compounds [4]. Among the possible chemicals, glycerol carbonate (GLC) is a useful chemical from glycerol as it has potential applications like gas separation, monomer of poly carbonate, green solvent, co-solvent in Li-ion batteries etc. [5]. Various approaches have been employed to synthesize GLC from glycerol. Different carbonate source such as phosgene, CO, CO2, urea and alkyl carbonates [5–8] was used for this reaction. The carbonylation of glycerol with phosgene or carbon monoxide is a traditional method, but it has been in practice due to the high toxicity of reactants. Recently urea, alkyl carbonates and CO2 have been used as carbonate sources. Using CO2 as a carbonate source for the synthesis of GLC is ideal approach. However, this method is limited due to difficulty in activating CO2 and the overall activity is very limited. In case of urea, the by-product NH3 needs to be removed continuously during the reaction. The transesterification of glycerol with dialkyl carbonate is important route to prepare GLC as these carbonate source is better than compared to other carbonate sources. Glycerol transesterification can be conducted by using base catalysts under homogeneous or heterogeneous conditions. Homogeneous bases, such as KOH, NaOH, and K2CO3, were active catalysts for glycerol transesterification. However, homogeneous catalysts have certain drawbacks [9]. Lipase Novozym 435, a enzymatic heterogeneous catalyst, reported for GLC synthesis [10]. Unfortunately, as for now this system is suffering from many drawbacks, such as high cost, poor activity and long reaction time. Heterogeneous catalysts such as, Mg–Al hydrotalcite [11], Mg/La mixed oxide [12], KF modified hydroxyapatite [13], CaO [9], CaO/Al2O3 [14], Mg1+xCa1−xO2 [15], KF/γ-Al2O3 [16], NaOH/γ- Al2O3 [17], and K2CO3/MgO [18] have been scrutinized for GLC synthesis. Recently, mixed oxides have been broadly applied as solid base catalysts for GLC synthesis as these materials posses strong basicity with large surface area compared to single metal oxides [19]. Among base metal oxides, magnesium oxide received much attention as a basic catalyst and support. Even though MgO is known for high basicity, many drawbacks like low reusability and less stability were associated. To overcome the difficulties associated with MgO, different mixed oxides have been prepared [20–29]. Ceria a wonderful metal oxide with wide applications particularly in catalysis studied extensively in recent years. CeO2 is an imperative metal oxide due to its distinctive acid-base and redox properties [30]. It is frequently used as support or catalyst. CeO2 as solid catalyst, showed exceptional activity in some reactions, such as alkylation [31], reduction of carboxylic acid [32] and alcohols dehydration [33]. Recently, CeO2 was employed as catalyst to prepare diverse cyclic carbonates from CO2 and diols [34]. Modification of ceria with other metal/metal oxide by substitution into its lattice to form mixed oxide is a better approach to modify the catalytic properties. The structural- electronic property of metal can be varied by the blend of two metals, subsequently favouring its activity and selectivity. It is anticipated to develop Mgo-CeO2 based mixed oxides to tune their catalytic properties towards the preparation of glycerol carbonate by glycerol transesterification. In the current work, a set of Mg/Ce mixed oxides were synthesized and their catalytic activity was evaluated for glycerol transesterification with DMC. DMC is substitute for conventional toxic and poisonous reagent such as phosgene and carbon monoxide. Moreover, because of its low toxicity, medium volatility, and high polarity. The effects of Mg/Ce ratio and treatment temperature were investigated. The role of surface-structural properties of the catalysts and their influence on transesterification activity is also the aim of the present study. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation Co-precipitation method was used to prepare MgO-CeO2 catalysts. On the basis of 10g of the final catalyst, required quantities of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O and Ce(NO3)3·6H2O were dissolved in de-ionised water and allowed to precipitate using 0.1M Na2CO3 and 0.1M NaOH mixture solution up to pH value reached 10 under constant stirring. The solution temperature was then raised to 80°C and maintained at same temperature for 2h with vigorous stirring. The precipitate was further aged at room temperature for 5h. Then the precipitate was collected after filtration and washed thoroughly. The obtained mass was dried at 110°C for 12h and finally calcined in a furnace at 650°C for 4h. MgO and CeO2 single oxides were individually precipitated from their respective nitrates adopting the above procedure. MgO and CeO2 catalyst with molar ratios of 1:1, 2:1, 1:2 and 3:1 were prepared and labelled as Mg1Ce1, Mg2Ce1, Mg1Ce2, and Mg3Ce1 respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization BET surface area of all the catalysts was calculated using Quantachrome Quadrasorb SI by N2 adsorption–desorption at liquid N2 temperature. The catalysts X -ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Rigaku Miniflex diffractometer using CuKα radiation (1.5406A°) at 40kV and 30mA. The measurements were captured in the 2θ range of 10–80°. TGA was performed with Q5000IR, TA Instruments. Samples of approximately 3–5mg were placed on aluminum pan. Data was obtained at a heating rate of 10°C/min in the temperature range of 100°C–1200°C. Morphology of the catalysts was observed by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, JEOL JSM-7610F) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) facility. Temperature programmed desorption of CO2 (TPD of CO2) was carried on BELCAT II instrument. The pre-treatment of samples was carried in He flow at 300°C for 1h, prior to CO2 adsorption at 70°C. The CO2adsorption was continued for 45min and then the sample was flushed with He for 1h at 100°C to remove physically adsorbed CO2 from catalyst surface. The desorption profile was recorded at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 from 100°C to 800°C and the desorbed CO2 was monitored with thermal conductivity detector. 2.3 Reaction procedure: transesterification of glycerol with DMC The transesterification reaction of glycerol was carried in liquid phase under atmospheric pressure. In a typical experiment, 2g of glycerol, 9.78g of DMC and 0.3g catalyst were taken into a 50ml capacity two-neck round-bottom flask containing reflux condenser. The reaction mixture was heated to 90°C while stirring on oil bath. After completion or desired time the reaction mixture was cooled and diluted with methanol. The catalyst was separated by filtration. Reaction mixture was analyzed by gas chromatograph (GC; Shimadzu 2010 plus, Japan) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) using Inno wax capillary column (30m×0.25mm×0.25μm). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts Table 1 represents the surface areas of Mg/Ce mixed oxides along with their monoxides. The catalysts surface area increased as the Mg to Ce molar ratio increases. An enhancement in surface area from 60 to 122m2 g−1 was noticed with enhancement in Mg content. The surface area of the catalysts was increased with increase in Ce content also. When Ce content is more (Mg1Ce2 catalyst) the surface area is also high (74m2 g−1) compared to the catalyst with less Ce content (Mg1Ce1). Fig. 1 represents the catalysts XRD profiles. The patterns of MgO and CeO2 were also included for comparison. The patterns indicate the crystalline nature of catalysts. The characteristic phases of CeO2 and MgO were seen for these catalysts and there was no formation of any mixed oxide phase. Diffraction peaks for pure MgO were noticed at 2θ of 37°, 42.7°, 49°, 62°, 75° and 78° which were assigned to cubic and hexagonal crystalline phases [12,15]. While the 2θ values at 28.8°, 33.3°, 47.7°, 56.6° and 70° were assigned to CeO2 phase [35–37]. In case of Mg/Ce oxide catalysts the crystalline phase of MgO was not observed. This indicates that MgO might be present in amorphous phase. CeO2 phases were predominant in mixed oxide catalysts. CO2 adsorption–desorption approach enables us to find out the base sites strength of catalyst together with total basicity. Fig. 2 shows the CO2-TPD profiles of the catalyst samples. The distribution of basicity was calculated depending on their strengths from the profiles and the calculated values are depicted in Table 1. The catalysts gave an intense desorption peak in 400–550°C temperature range. Desorption peaks intensity was increased with enhancement in the ratio of Mg to Ce and also the peak shifted to high temperature. This indicates that with raise in Mg/Ce ratio not only the number of basic sites but also their strength was increased. The Mg3Ce1catalyst (Mg/Ce ratio of 3:1) exhibited more number of sites with strong basicity. The peak at elevated temperature might be related to strong basic sites associated to oxygen in M2+-O2− pairs. The high basicity for the Mg3Ce1 catalyst was related to the availability of more number of oxygen anions of MgO which is present in high ratio. It was reported that, the concentration and strength of basic sites improved with increase in MgO content in mixed oxide catalysts [29,38–40]. In case of Mg1Ce2, where Ce content is more, showed two low intense broad desorption peaks at 250 and 450°C related weak and moderate basic sites. This indicates that at high CeO2 content the catalyst contains only moderate amount of basic sites. The thermal stabilities of Mg3Ce1 mixed oxide catalyst was investigated by Thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA) and the thermogram are shown in Fig. 3 . Thermogram of Mg3Ce1 catalyst displays two stage weight losses. The initial weight loss which was observed at 120°C was mainly due to the removal of residual water from the sample. The second weight loss which occurred in 300–500°C range was due to evolution of CO2 and decomposition of oxycarbonate to get stable metal oxides. The TG curve showed no noticeable weight loss above 500°C which was credited to formation of stable MgO/CeO2 mixed oxide. In DTA curve at about 120°C an endothermic peak was observed that corresponding to desorption of water. The endothermic peak at 200–250°C was assigned to solid reaction and/or phase transition of catalyst. The characterization results suggested that MgO-CeO2 mixed oxide catalysts are crystalline in nature with reasonable surface area, thermal stability and strong basicity. 3.2 Catalytic activity The Mg/Ce catalysts activity was tested for the transesterification glycerol with DMC and the data is concisely depicted in Table 2 . The reaction in absence of any catalyst was carried and about 5% GLC yield was noticed. The reaction was also tested using MgO and CeO2 as catalysts for comparison. MgO showed about 26% yield, whereas CeO2 exhibited 9% yield of GLC. The Mg/Ce mixed oxides exceptionally exhibited good activity towards glycerol transesterification with DMC. The conversion levels were varied with composition of the catalysts. The activity increased considerably when the Mg to Ce molar ratio increased from 1 to 3 in the catalyst. Mg3Ce1 catalyst showed maximum activity among the other catalysts with 100% selectivity. These results put forward that the activity of the base catalyzed reaction can be enhanced by using mixed oxide catalysts. The catalyst with high CeO2 content (Mg1Ce2) showed similar activity as that of Mg1Ce1 catalyst. This indicates that no appreciable increment in activity with raise in CeO2 content in mixed oxide catalyst. This describes that Ce is mainly accountable for the selective formation of GLC, whereas Mg enhances the conversion of glycerol. The transesterification activity observed for the Mg/Ce catalysts can be correlated from the derived catalyst characteristics. The Mg3Ce1 catalyst exhibited strong basic sites. This catalyst contains well defined crystalline sites of CeO2 and MgO is present in high dispersed state within the mixed oxide. The base strength distribution has control on the transesterification activity, where the strong basic sites stimulate glycerol conversion and moderate base sites have an influence on GLC yield. Accordingly, the weak basic sites mainly related to OH− groups present on the catalyst surface, while the medium and strong basic strength are related to the oxygen of Mn+–O2− ion pairs and isolated O2− anions, which are generally considered as Lewis basic sites of the metal oxides. The reasonable activity of Mg1Ce1, Mg2Ce1 catalysts was owed to the existence of moderate basic sites. The results advocate that the catalyst basicity is the main factor in obtaining high GLC yield. It is illustrious that the basicity of mixed oxides relays not only on the metal composition but also on the calcination temperature. Therefore, additional improvement in basicity and thereby catalytic activity of Mg3Ce1 catalyst can be achieved by varying calcination temperature. 3.3 Effect of calcination temperature of catalyst on activity In order to know the surface-structural variation of catalysts with change in catalyst calcination, Mg3Ce1 catalyst was exposed to calcination at different temperatures ranging from 450 to 750°C and studied for their transesterification activity. The catalysts activities are presented in Table 3 . The results signify that with enhancement in calcination temperature a significant improvement in glycerol conversion from 46 to 86% was noticed. In all the cases, GLC selectivity was 100%. The catalyst treated at 750°C, showed relatively less glycerol conversion. In order to explicate the variation in activity and structural changes in Mg3Ce1 catalyst with calcination temperature, catalysts were subjected to characterization by XRD and TPD of CO2. The XRD profiles of Mg3Ce1 catalyst calcined at varying temperatures are drawn in Fig. 4 . The catalyst crystalline behaviour increased with the rise in calcination temperature. Mg3Ce1 sample subjected to calcinations at 450°C showed diffraction pattern similar to the patterns of CeO2 phase. The catalyst treated at 550°C showed CeO2 peaks with dissimilar intensities. Interestingly, for this sample the peaks at 37.5° and 43.2° were increased which corresponds to CeO2 and MgO respectively. Further increase to 650°C, CeO2 crystalline phases were formed with well dispersed MgO. At high temperature calcination (750°C), the intensity of peaks at 37.5° and 43.2° were decreased and the same time the strength of peak at 47.7° was increased. During the calcination at 750°C, interlayer distance was slightly decreased. XRD results suggest considerable structural changes occurred during calcination at 550–750°C. These results imply that MgO was in highly dispersed state and CeO2 was in crystalline phase when subjected to 650°C. Further to see the change in the increase in crystallinity the active Mg3Ce1 catalyst calcined at low and temperature was studied by FE-SEM. The images of SEM are presented in Fig. 5 . The images clearly indicate the change in crystallinity with calcinations temperature. These results are in support of the observations made from XRD. Fig. 6 represents the TPD of CO2 profiles of Mg3Ce1 catalyst treated at 450–750°C. With the vary in the temperature from 450 to 650°C, the desorption peak present at 400–600°C intensity was increased. The catalyst treated at lower temperature (450°C) showed broader desorption peak than catalysts treated at higher temperatures. However, the sample calcined at 550°C has desorption peaks related to weak and strong basic sites. A very strong desorption peak was obtained the catalyst exposed to 650°C. A distinguishable change in the basicity profile was there for the sample exposed to 750°C. The presence of crystalline MgO in the 750°C calcined catalyst might be responsible for the decrease in basicity. As the MgO dispersion, which is mainly accountable for basicity, is lowered because of crystalline nature of MgO. The declaim in activity for the catalyst treated at 750°C might be related to the non availability of well dispersed MgO. Another probable reason for low activity is the partial elimination of the binding water molecules from the catalyst structure, that could possibly led to the destabilization of the binary oxide system and thereby the formation of unknown species of those metals (Mg, Ce). In comparison with other temperatures, catalyst treated at 650°C yielded high activity. The high activity for this catalyst is mainly owing to the availability of high amount of basicity with reasonable amount of strong basic sites. These results along with XRD results mean that calcination temperature is an important factor for the preparation of Mg/Ce base catalysts. 3.4 Possible reaction mechanism Transesterification of glycerol over base catalysts to yield GLC, the essential requirement is the activation of glycerol primary hydroxyl group. Base catalysts with strong basic strength could activate glycerol primary hydroxyl group. The plausible mechanism over the MgO-CeO2 is proposed and illustrated in Scheme 1 . The present catalyst contains strong basic sites (M2+-O2− ions) which are observed from TPD-CO2 can abstract proton of hydroxyl group to form glyceroxide anion. This anion then attacks DMC carbonyl carbon to form methyl glycerate carbonate by eliminating methanol as represented in step 3 along with generation of basic site. Then the methyl glyceryl carbonate undergoes cyclization reaction by nucleophylic attack of the oxygen of the secondary hydroxyl group to the carbonyl carbon to yield GLC along with one more methanol molecule. 3.5 Effect of reaction conditions on the yield of glycerol carbonate The consequence of different parameters such like reaction temperature, catalyst concentration, glycerol to DMC molar ratio, and reaction time were considered to rationalize GLC yield during glycerol transesterification. The active Mg3Ce1 catalyst was used to optimize the reaction parameters. The reaction temperature effect on the performance of Mg3Ce1 catalyst was investigated and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . When temperature increased from 50 to 90°C, GLC yield increased from 39 to 86%. Further enhancement in reaction temperature to 110°C, no improvement in conversion was noticed. The decrease in GLC yield at high reaction temperature approves that side-reactions (dehydrogenation-condensation) by the by-product methanol could occur on basic sites. In literature, the preparation of GLC was carried at varying temperatures between 50 and 120°C at atmosphere pressure [12,15]. The metal oxides showed about 40% GLC yield at 50°C and further increased with temperature [29,38,41]. When hydrotalcite and ionic liquid are used as catalysts, higher temperatures of 100–120°C are required to obtain reasonable GLC yield [11,42]. The suitable reaction temperature for the glycerol transesterification is 90°C for Mg3Ce1 catalyst. The role of reaction time was investigated with time intervals of 30–120min at 90°C and the results are drawn in Fig. 8 . The yield increased as the reaction time changed from 30 to 90min. Glycerol conversion was increased steadily within 90min and reached up to 86% to GLC. Thereafter the conversion and yield remained constant with reaction time. Many literature reports investigated that, the conversion rate of glycerol, selectivity and GLC yield increase with reaction time [17,18,29,38,41]. The GLC yield improved from 75% to 99% when the reaction time had increased from 1 to 2h [11]. The present catalyst exhibited optimum activity within 90min. Fig. 9 presents the yields obtained during glycerol transesterification by varying the reactants molar ratios. When glycerol to DMC molar ratio is 1:3, the conversion was only 41%. The alter in molar ratio from 1:3 to 1:5, glycerol conversion improved from 41 to 86%. In other words, an increase in DMC concentration, conversion and yield of GLC was increased. Stoichiometrically, one mole DMC is necessary for each mole of glycerol to yield GLC. However, higher molar ratio is necessary to oblige the reaction in the direction of completion to yield more GLC. Further enhancement in glycerol to DMC molar ratio, a marginal drop in conversion and yield was noticed. The optimum molar ratio to produce GLC was 1:5. Fig. 10 shows the result obtained by changing the catalyst amounts on glycerol transesterification. An increase in catalyst concentration led to noticeable change in glycerol conversion was observed. About 86% yield was obtained when the catalyst concentration was 15%. This is linked to proportional increase of active sites. Further change in concentration of catalyst to 20%, glycerol conversion was decreased marginally. This decrease is associated to the raise in resistance of mass transfer in solid catalyst-glycerol-DMC tri phase system. A clear aggregation of catalyst was noticed when catalyst amount increased beyond 15wt%. 3.6 Optimized reaction conditions Based on the studies carried by varying the reaction parameters, the optimium conditions for the high activity of Mg3Ce1 catalysts are presented in Table 4 . The best GLC yied of 86% was obtained at a reaction temperature of 90°C with in 90min of reaction time with a catalyst concentration of 15%. The suitable glycerol to DMC molar ratio is 1:5 to acgeive optimum activity over Mg3Ce1 catalyst. 4 Conclusion In summary, Mgo-CeO2 are competent catalysts for selective preparation of glycerol carbonate by transesterification of glycerol with dimethyl carbonate. The investigations indicate that mixed oxide catalysts activity was higher compared to mono oxides. The catalysts performance was depended on the mole ratio of Mg and Ce and the catalyst with MgO to CeO2 mole ratio of 3:1 showed maximum activity due to the presence of strong basic sites. The activity of the catalysts depends on the catalyst calcination temperature. Catalyst calcination temperature has significant effect on catalysts characteristics and thereby on transesterification activity. The GLC yield depends on reaction parameters such as reaction time, temperature, molar ratio of glycerol to DMC and catalyst concentration. The optimum reaction parameters were established. coredata.dc:description: MgO-CeO2 catalysts were investigated for selective synthesis of glycerol carbonate by glycerol transesterification with dimethyl carbonate as carbonating source. Co-precipitation technique was used to prepare Mg-Ce oxides by with different molar ratios. Samples characteristics were derived by N2 adsorption, XRD, FE-SEM, TGA-DTA and CO2 -TPD. The catalysts surface structural properties and basicity were directed by the composition of oxides and treatment temperature. The sample with 3:1 Mg/Ce ratio exhibited highest basicity. The same catalyst treated at a temperature of 650°C, exhibited highest glycerol carbonate yield of 86%. The reaction conditions were also optimized.
